_comment: Created by ianb on 27/04/2015 18:13:18 using v2.5
title: How many days in total are patients delayed by the type of care received?
analysis_commentary: There is currently large variation in the number of days a patient is likely to be delayed based on the type of care that they received. Delays in transfer from acute care and non-acute care were very similar in August 2010, however, from that point onwards the total number of days delayed accrued in a month have diverged between the care settings. The number of days delayed per month in acute care has increased by approximately 64% between August 2010 (55,332 days) and February 2015 (90,705 days). The number of days delayed per month in non-acute care has decreased by approximately 20% between August 2010 (54,586 days) and February 2015 (43,803 days).
data_source: NHS England, Delayed transfer of care
